goal.tools.debugger

Class SteppingDebugger

  • java.lang.Object
    • goal.tools.debugger.SteppingDebugger
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Debugger
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    ObservableDebugger

    public class SteppingDebugger
extends java.lang.Object
implements Debugger

    Provides two functions:

    • Provides control over the run mode of an agent.
    • Provides listener functionality so that others can hear about debug events happening here.

    There is exactly 1 debugger for each agent, but at several places we create temporary Debuggers when we do some "dirty" coding by directly calling the agent's databases. These temporary debuggers avoid the user seeing breakpoints occur when he for example makes a manual query in the debugger, or when the initialization is being done of the databases.

    In the core, various breakpoints have been defined for agents. At each of these breakpoints, an agent will call SteppingDebugger#breakpoint(String, Channel). Upon such calls, the debugger checks whether any DebugObserver that subscribed to the debugger wants to view messages associated with the breakpoint.

    If someone (not necessarily a DebugObserver) wants to pause on a breakpoint, the debugger enforces this and makes the agent pause on the next breakpoint.

    The debugger is used to view debug events as follows:

    1. Create a DebugObserver and implement its interface.
    2. #subscribe(DebugObserver) the DebugObserver to interact with the debugger of the agent.
    3. Call #addPause(DebugObserver, Channel) and #subscribe(DebugObserver, Channel) as necessary.
    4. Run the agent.

    See also the notes with #breakpoint(String, Channel)

    We currently do not use a standard Observer/Observable pattern because agents may not be interested in all events, depending on the debug settings.

    To control the debugger and the agent running, you can directly call finestep(), step() and run(). To kill the agent, call kill().

    Author:
    W.Pasman June 2008

      • SteppingDebugger

        public SteppingDebugger(java.lang.String name,
                EnvironmentPort env)
        Creates debugger for given label. Names other than agent names are used for temporary debuggers. By default a new debugger has SteppingDebugger.RunMode.RUNNING and Channel.REASONING_CYCLE_SEPARATOR enabled.
        Parameters:
        name - The name of the debugger.
        env - The current environment (if any), used when the 'new agents copy environment run state' option is enabled.

      • SteppingDebugger

        public SteppingDebugger(AgentId id,
                EnvironmentPort env)
        Creates debugger for given agent. By default a new debugger has SteppingDebugger.RunMode.RUNNING and Channel.REASONING_CYCLE_SEPARATOR enabled.
        Parameters:
        id - The relevant agent (its name will be used for the debugger).
        env - The current environment (if any), used when the 'new agents copy environment run state' option is enabled.

      • setRunMode

        public void setRunMode(SteppingDebugger.RunMode mode)
        Changes the run mode. Only notifies observers of a change in run mode.

        Also wakes up the debugged thread of the agent, to check if it can proceed running.

        Parameters:

      • setKeepRunning

        public void setKeepRunning(boolean bool)

      • breakpoint

        public void breakpoint(Channel channel,
              java.lang.Object associate,
              java.lang.String message,
              java.lang.Object... args)
        Description copied from interface: Debugger

        Informs the debugger that the thread under debug has reached a breakpoint. This method should be called only by the agent, never by an external thread. The call blocks if the breakpoint is in the #pausingChannels. It unblocks only after someone calls the debug control functions such as #run().
        If we notice the runmode is SteppingDebugger.RunMode.KILLED, ThreadDeath is thrown.

        *

        Usage of breakpoint():
        A call to breakpoint() may be inserted BEFORE the agent action takes place, so the debugger can indicate what the system is going to do, as well as AFTER the agent action has taken place. Doing so enables a programmer to see what is scheduled to happen BEFORE the action occurs, and to check what has happened after the action has been performed in order to identify any problems due to the action and in order to facilitate an effective analysis (this allows a programmer to check its expectations).

        IMPORTANT: do NOT place a #breakpoint(String, Channel, Object) inside a synchronized block if you want to support multi-threading.

        It is recommended to use past tense for breakpoints reporting an event that has happened, and to use future tense for events that are going to happen after the breakpoint.

        Specified by:
        breakpoint in interface Debugger
        Parameters:
        channel - channel on which to the breakpoint message is reported. Also see class Channel.
        associate - The object being associated with the breakpoint. May be null if the breakpoint is not associated with any object. See GOALProgram#getBreakpointObjects() for which IParsedObjects the user can put a breakpoint on.
        message - is a user-readable message that describes the breakpoint event.
        args - Any additional arguments to embed in the message

      • awaitKilled

        public void awaitKilled()
        Returns when killed mode is entered. TODO: work in progress; we need to create some method to be sure that the agent has been completely terminated, i.e., the thread is gone (or, ThreadDeath has been thrown which is as close as we can get I guess). The idea here is to introduce another RunMode state called TOBEKILLED (at which point an InterruptException is thrown); KILLED state then is reached at the next breakpoint where the run mode is updated again (and ThreadDeath is thrown).

      • step

        public void step()
        Puts the SteppingDebugger in SteppingDebugger.RunMode.STEPPING mode. The debugger will then halt on the first breakpoint that someone is listening to.

      • finestep

        public void finestep()
        Puts the SteppingDebugger in SteppingDebugger.RunMode.FINESTEPPING mode.

      • run

        public void run()
        Puts the SteppingDebugger into SteppingDebugger.RunMode.RUNNING mode.

      • kill

        public void kill()
        Set the agent's run mode to SteppingDebugger.RunMode.KILLED and set status of current thread to interrupted.

        Interrupting the thread does not completely kill the agent; the idea instead is to throw ThreadDeath when the agent hits the next breakpoint (or is already at a breakpoint), which should terminate the Thread in which the agent runs.

        Assumes the agent (and its debugger) are running in its own thread.

        Specified by:
        kill in interface Debugger

      • addPause

        public void addPause(Channel channel)
        add channel to pause channels. Thread will be paused when agent hits breakpoint on this channel. See also DebugSettingSynchronizer.
        Parameters:
        channel - is channel that causes agent to pause.

      • removePause

        public void removePause(Channel channel)
        remove channel from pause channels. Agent will not be paused anymore when agent hits breakpoint on this channel.
        Parameters:
        channel - is channel that causes agent to pause.
